bioghist.p: Rev. Alexander A. Pieters (d. 1958) was born in Russia where he completed high school before immigrating to the United States. He graduated from McCormick Theological Seminary in Chicago in 1902. He married his first wife, the former Miss Eva H. Field, M.D., in 1908. She died in 1932. He married Anne L. Cooper (d. 1974) in 1934. Pieters did missionary service in the Philippines, and was then transferred to Korea, where he preached, taught, and conducted Bible institutes in rural areas. Pieters was a translator of the Old Testament and other religious books into Korean and was editor of a Korean/English dictionary. He retired in 1941.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of Pieters family papers. Materials include correspondence of the Pieters family (1924-1941), much of it from Eva and Alexander and later from Anne and Alexander Pieters to their sons. The letters discuss family matters, their visitors and social life in Korea, Alexanderâ€™s work with TB and leprosy, and some local, national, and world events. Of particular interest is a letter from Alexander to Reuben about his Jewish heritage and the family's response to it. The collection also includes: books in Korean translated by A. A. Pieters -- including bibles and school texts; information card possibly from the Board of Foreign Missions on Pieters' missionary work, including postings, furloughs, personal information, and denominational affiliation; scrapbook for A. A. Pieters' 70th birthday, including letters and photographs; bound copies of Reminiscences by Richard S. Pieters; biography of A. A. Pieters, compiled by Norma Kenfield Pieters; UPC in the USA memorial minutes and obituary for A. A. Pieters, 1958; lesson book, created by Richard Pieters as a child while educated in the mission field in the 1910s; 1926 yearbook of Richard Peters from the Mercersburg Academy, (Pennsylvania); diaries of Eva H. Field describing work in Korea between 1898 and 1904; letters from Anne to her mother (1934-1941); and photographs.
